title: Deutsche Schrift
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Blackletter](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Blackletter) : Deutsche Schrift**

Probably the largest family of [Blackletter](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Blackletter) types ever cast, the Deutsche Schrift was the first of [Rudolf Koch](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Rudolf%20Koch)'s designs for the [Klingspor](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Klingspor) foundry. More weights would be added by Koch, the [Klingspor](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Klingspor)s, and by [D. Stempel AG](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/D.%20Stempel%20AG) until the second World War.

Family members include:  
Deutsche Schrift (1908)?  
Deutsche Schrägschrift

Deutsche Anzeigenschrift (Anzeigenschrift means Headline Face)  
- breiter Schnitt (extended)  
- schmaler Schnitt (condensed)  
- schmaler, halbfetter Schnitt (condensed, semi bold) this was the default design  
- enger Schnitt (ultra condensed)

Deutsche Zierschrift (a outlined and engraved version)

Deutsche Werkschrift (Werkschrift means Bookface)  
- mager (regular)  
- halbfett (semi bold)

Koch wasn't very much in love with this typeface, but due to its great commercial success [D. Stempel AG](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/D.%20Stempel%20AG) and [Klingspor](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Klingspor) forced extensions to the family. (1910 to at least 1921; some of the Anzeigenschriften were cut during the 1930s).

[Maximillian](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Maximillian) is a similar design to the Deutsche Schrift. Presumably, Koch have better feelings about [Maximillian](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901145307/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Maximillian)…
author: paul d hunt
